DOCNAME: CASE OF ELIAZER v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of Art. 6-3-c;No violation of Art. 14+6
TEXT: CARDINAL . By summons of CARDINAL DATE the applicant was ordered to appear on DATE before ORG ( PERSON in PERSON ) of GPE on charges of possession of QUANTITY of cocaine .

CARDINAL . By judgment of DATE , following adversarial proceedings in the course of which the applicant was assisted by a lawyer , ORG acquitted the applicant . The prosecution filed an appeal with ORG ( FAC ) of GPE and GPE .

CARDINAL . As the applicant had failed to appear before ORG of Justice at its first hearing on the appeal on DATE , he was declared in default of appearance ( verstek ) . ORG of Justice adjourned the proceedings until DATE . The applicant also failed to appear on DATE . On DATE , ORG of Justice resumed the proceedings and examined the appeal . The applicant ’s lawyer attended this hearing and conducted the applicant ’s defence .

CARDINAL . By judgment of DATE , following proceedings in absentia , ORG of ORG quashed the judgment of DATE , convicted the applicant of having violated section CARDINAL ) of LAW of GPE ( DATE ) and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .
CARDINAL . Relying on LAW for GPE and GPE ( ORG en GPE ) , the applicant filed an appeal in cassation with ORG ( PERSON ) , which appeal is limited to points of law and procedural conformity .
CARDINAL . In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG noted that , pursuant to LAW for GPE and GPE , no appeal in cassation lay against judgments pronounced following proceedings in absentia .

CARDINAL . It rejected the argument advanced by the defence , that the appeal in cassation should nevertheless be declared admissible on the ground that this provision of LAW was contrary to LAW in that it constituted an unjustified difference in treatment between persons tried in adversarial proceedings and persons tried in proceedings in absentia .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that , according to LAW ) , a person convicted on appeal following proceedings in absentia could file an objection ( verzet ) against this conviction . If the accused then appeared before the trial court , the case would , pursuant to LAW , be fully retried by the same court in the course of adversarial proceedings and an appeal in cassation would lie against the resulting judgment .

CARDINAL . ORG concluded that , in the circumstances , no appeal in cassation lay against the judgment of DATE . However , on the basis of the contents of a statement made on DATE on behalf of the applicant , ORG interpreted the applicant ’s appeal in cassation as being an objection against his conviction in absentia and ordered the transmission of the applicant ’s case file to ORG of Justice for a determination of the applicant ’s objection .

CARDINAL . According to LAW as in force at the relevant time , an appeal to ORG of Justice lies against a judgment given by ORG . This appeal is a full appeal , that is , CARDINAL comprising both fact and law .

CARDINAL . Under LAW for GPE and GPE an appeal in cassation may be filed with ORG against judgments on appeal given by ORG of GPE and GPE . Such an appeal in cassation is limited to procedural conformity and points of law .
CARDINAL . According to LAW , a person convicted by ORG in absentia may file an objection ( verzet ) against this conviction .

CARDINAL . If the accused then appears at the hearing on the objection before ORG , the case will , pursuant to LAW , be fully retried by that court . An appeal in cassation lies against the resulting judgment .
CARDINAL . If the accused does not appear before ORG of Justice for the purpose of a retrial , the objection will be declared defunct and the judgment given in absentia will become final .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § QUANTITY of LAW for GPE and GPE reads as follows :
“ The accused can not file an appeal in cassation against judgments given in absentia [ bij verstek gewezen vonnissen ] . ”
CARDINAL . According to the explanatory memorandum to LAW for GPE and GPE ( PERSON , PERSON , GPE DATE ( R DATE ) , no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL ) , LAW was based on the following considerations :

“ ... given the great distance between the seat of ORG and GPE , it is not to be recommended to provide for an appeal in cassation in NORP cases in all cases , where this is possible for cases in the GPE ... In general the suspect himself will be to blame that his case has been dealt with in absentia . In these circumstances , there is no cause to attach more weight to his interests than to the inconveniences which are attached to proceedings in cassation in respect of overseas cases . ”
